I will go to quotes by Washington before any other American, because he was closest to the core when this country was made, he understood more clearly than any single man what this country was founded on, and what it should mean and become - and lastly, he was the most selfless, fully American of all the Founding Fathers. You are an individual among 350 million. You may divorce yourself from religion while still trying to parallel its concepts, stripped of belief, and be a moral good person...but even in doing that, you are basing your actions on religious principles, because only religion can put any real meaning in a statement like, "Human life is sacred." A group of humans can get together and pass a rule that killing humans is wrong and should be punished, but it has no "moral" authority, since even the turn "moral" becomes just one more opinion - - Without a "God" there are really only two actual laws that govern life: "Survival of the fittest" and "What's yours is mine, if I can figure out a way to get it or take it." Those who disavow "God" take on all the advantages of acting in any manor they wish, without conscience...the criminal mind, the Nazi Hitler, the robber baron business man, the mafia don, the drug cartel leader... If you decide to superimpose on yourself a desire to "be morally good," even though atheist, what do you use as a "moral compass" to know you are being morally good? Al Capone or the teaching of Jesus? Machiavelli or Plato? Karl Marx or Gandhi? Mao or Buddha? Pharaoh or Moses? Madoff or Martin Luther King? There are not too many out there who have shaped our concepts of "good" over the millennia by relative ethics or "Natural Law"... They have been profound religious teachers - - The French, during the "Age of Reason" tried to latch onto Science and Logic as a substitute or replacement for religious morality, also trying to abandon emotion for logic... But love is not logical. Compassion is not logical. Sympathy is not logical... Morality and Goodness are not logical. Survival of self at any cost is totally logical... Today, we are in the grip of "relative ethics" "Natural Law", and "Social Darwinsm" - all of which are very Machiavellian in their concepts of "Whatever works is good and right" "Survival of the fittest in the business place", and "the end justifies the mean." A country without a moral compass and rudder must eventually spin out of control, because no one knows where it should go, and there is no way to guide or steer it - - Doesn't that describe America today? Where are we going? What should we be and do? Where should we be leading the world to? Why should we be leading at all? Why should anyone want to follow us? Why should anyone be upset about GITMO?? Explain to me what the true essence of "good and moral" is if there is no God - - Wandering and Wondering
